I used a sketchup plugin called "Draw Ring" to design a bracelet with my daughter picking our her favourite designs and colours at the same time. This is the final version with an inner circle diameter of 6cm so it should be a snug fit on her wrist, she is 5. I also had a special request from my youngest daughter who is 2 for one also, so there is a second model on here too, its 5cm on the inside. If you would like a different size let me know and I can upload it here too. I wonder if I my wife would wear this too, probably not ;-)   
I am using a local 3D printer to print this out in the next few days so I will upload some photos as soon as its done. www.3dhubs.com.  
Also, there is a HQ version with more "faces" and a medium quality, so I'm not sure if it is enough to change the print quality but hopefully it is nice and smooth.  
I have uploaded some different vesions because the first one I printed was a bit too big. I figure little hands will be able to squeeze into the bracelet given the twits in the bracelet actually allow more room than the sketchup dimension allow.

Amie file is 6cm inner diameter
Emily file is 5cm inner diameter

This is a compact enclosure I designed for my simple four-LED binary clock. The case is designed to hold a small PCB along with two pushbuttons. The cutouts in the front panel allow these buttons to pressed through the plastic-covered printed paper artwork. An example of a suitable front panel is shown in the pictures below.  
I've uploaded this object here because it might have wider use than just my original binary clock application. The enclosure includes a hole for a power cable. I've also attached the DesignSpark Mechanical files for those wanting to adapt the design for their own requirements.  
The electronics are described over on my website at www.zl2pd.com if anyone is remotely interested.

I printed this using PLA filament on my Printrbot Simple Metal using 0.2mm layers and a shell thickness of 0.8mm. I set fill density to 15%.   
I don't have a heated bed so I printed it base downwards, just as it sits on the table in use, directly on printer's tape without any additional support.

Simple door catch to stop doors slamming. I designed this little catch because I had a couple of doors that slammed closed when I opened windows for a through draft. I've printed mine in ABS. First design has been in use for at least 4 months and is still going strong. V2 was a very slight redesign of the base plate for added strength if hit by vacuum cleaners. Disclaimer:
Obviously this catch should not be used to keep fire safety doors open! Fire doors should remain closed whenever possible to prevent potential fires spreading.

At the flee market this weekend I found a board game from my childhood, so of course, I bought it for my child. Unfortunately it was missing one of the plastic feet for the game pieces. So, I broke out the calipers and got scading. The piece is designed for the great game Mausefalle (http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/25097/mausefalle), but it should work with little or no modification with many a great board game with cardboard cutout game pieces. (ie: Candy Land) Now I just need to find the rules for Mausfalle, since I don't remember how to get out of the mouse holes...
For Mausefalle, just print and enjoy.  For other games, you may need to adjust the size for the thickness of the cardboard piece, or the length of the piece.

title: Immortan Joe Mask

description.text: It's designed to print as a very thin shell so that you can accomodate any padding you wish, heat-bend it to whatever fit you desire. Feel free to modify it (it might need it) Also, a resize might be in order as I have a pretty slim face and I modelled it on my own photogrammetric scan.

It's still printing! I plan to use it as a guide for further FIMO enhacement and then painting. Will post photos of the finished thing - after I'm done.
  • Support is a must for the lower half.

Ball bearing supported stand-alone universal spool holder. NB: Print in mm for correct size. I wanted a spool holder, I couldn't find one that met my needs (I didn't look too hard), I made one that does. Hence, one extremely smooth, rugged and easy to use universal spool holder. Initially I thought it might be too smooth (i.e. just keep rolling even when the printer isn't pulling material), but I've been using it since January 2015 and it’s been working perfectly. It supports virtually any spool type: in reality that means spools ranging from a 40mm to 130mm width, 40mm to 60mm inner diameter and pretty much any weight (relative to the range of spool widths). What you'll need for the build:
• 1 x Bolt: 100mm length with 6mm diameter (and 1 x nut to match).
• 2 x Ball bearing: 22mm outer diameter, 7.8mm inner (bore) diameter and 7mm width.
• 1 x PVC Pipe: 40mm diameter with 490mm length (cut into 2 x 140mm, 1 x 120mm and 2 x 45mm length pieces).
• 3 x 90deg elbow joint: to join the 40mm diameter pipes (one of these links to the PVC Connector).
• 1 x Equal tee joint: to join the 40mm diameter pipes. I'll leave it as a puzzle because it’s not hard and I'm too lazy to type out the instructions. You got this. Since I have an Up Plus 2, I created a filament guide for use with this spool holder. You can find that here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:891379 Enjoy

Milton is a low-poly Parasaurolophus intended for use as a replacement robber token for Settlers of Catan. Unlike Robber Rex, Milton prefers quiet contemplation to the sacking and pillaging lifestyle, and spends a great deal of time working up the courage to post anonymously on Jezebel comment threads. Read a little short fiction about Milton over at the blog.

description.text:
Hi Folk i like challenges, so i decided to join the S.T.E.A.M. - MakeItFloat 
This is my first challenge thingiverse. So I started with my colleague to find a good mix of real solutions for transport of heavy Wight. We found something. This is the second concept of our total 3 ideas for this challenge. Hopefully we have enough time to generate, print and test all 3 concepts. Focus on this Concept:
1.Print less parts and support structures as possible
2.Carry heavy load -> 2 Euro coins (diameter: 25,75 mm, thickness: 2,20 mm, weight: 8,50 g) - this was my first idea but i had not so much 2 Euro coins... So, i used all coins what i had.
3.Priority: load > design
4.Must be take a lot of load This can be print on an area of 200x200x180mm with PLA. i modified the design a few times. i tried it can hold a lot of coins, 1 beer cane (0,5l) and a lit pit ice. the new design should work better, it means it should carry more ice for the beer ;). i have seen when i i place a can in it, that the Center of gravity is high. so i lowered the actual design now.
THE END - 19.07.2015 Update
Update of concept
STL file prepared
Now, I need to print and test :) 23.06.2015
Update
i printed the legs of my design and i saw it was not stable. so i added a stiffener now. i will print and test it. 27.06.2015
Update
concept printed and assemblied. i will try to test it on the Weekend.
photo added. - 02.07.2015
Update
first test in the water done. it swims really good. i made a Picture of the device with a can of 0,5l beer on it. (it is not best beer but it is a beer.). so, it is perfect for the pool :)
i will make a Picture with coins in it, next time. - 04.07.2015
Update
small modifications and some covers prepared.
also closed the bottom area of the Box - water tight
Picture uploaded - 09.07.2015
Update
changed main description and photos added. Basic instruction added. - 19.07.2015

i printed it with the new slic3r Version 1.2.9 it is possible to print the parts without any Support material and less infill, it means the most is hollow!
Material: PLA Legs:
Layer height: 0,3mm
Vertical shells for the wall: minimum 4 better 5 (nozzle Diameter 0,4mm)
Infill: 15% with honeycomb if needed
bottom sheel should have also Minimum 4 shells Container + cover:
Layer height: 0,3mm
Vertical shells for the wall: minimum 2 better 3 (nozzle Diameter 0,4mm)
Infill: 15% with 3d honeycomb

title: Velleman K8200 & 3DRAG - Camera Holder for Logitech C200 (or other similar) on end of ALFER Coaxis exstrusion for Octoprint

description.text:
I wanted to mount my camera with style. As such I had an end of the
Alfer Coaxis extrusion left from stiffening up the frame of the K8200. So it was an easy exercise to do, but looks great. BTW you have to take the camera to pieces and re-assemble it.
(There are also some How-To's in the net to support you, but it is pretty straight forward and easy) In that process I spray-painted the case of the camera black. Just for the looks of it. I used this in the process:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247948

No

description.text:
When stacking the spools i got a big mess because the filament never stayed on the spool and unwinded itself. The holes on the spools are most times not enogh, on the wrong place and when you use them the filament sticks out on one side. There are three versions for the three diffrent types of spools i encountered. 2.85mm and 3mm filement stays in fine, for 1.75mm filament you need a good printing quality. If you have any idea to improve it please tell me.

V-Slot z-stage for Ultimaker Original
This is a drop-in replacement for the z-stage to accommodate the MK3 Aluminium heated bed. Alternative parts to accommodate my original 3-point levelled heated bed set up (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84754) are also provided.

Print all parts in ABS at 100% infill with 0.2mm layer.
Print all V-Slot cross-section mating parts with the V ceiling pointing up to avoid supports.
The support seats will have to be printed with support for the rail keys.
Thumbwheels do not need any support for the nut cavity.
Print the anti-twist caps holes facing down for strength. Parts referred to "old glass" are to accommodate my original heated bed set up (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:84754). Mind you that you may have to unglue and reposition the washers receiving the ball magnets. Bill of Materials: 2x V-Slot 20x20 length:270mm
1x V-Slot 20x20 length:180mm
1x V-Slot 20x20 length:140mm
6x M5x15 flat head socket screws
4x M5x8 flat head socket screws
2x M5x10 flat head socket screws
1x M5x15 flat head socket screw
13x V-Slot slide in tee nuts (http://www.makerstore.com.au/product/slide-in-tee-nuts-25-pack/)
3x M3x30 socket head cap screws
6x M3 washers
1x M3x20 socket head cap screw
3x spring (original Ultimaker springs)
3x Ball magnets (7mm diameter)
2x M3x5 socket head cap screws
2x M3 nuts
1x M2x5 socket head cap screw
1x M2 nuts
2x M2 washers
3x M3x10 spacer nuts (normal nuts will do too)
2x V-Slot corner brackets
1 big bag to contain all the above (optional) For automagical assembly, place all components in the bag and shake! :))

This is a small rubber band powered catapult based off of a paperboard model (see images). The 3D printable parts may have slight differences from the parts shown assembled, but fit together the same. NOTE: Be sure to print this model in extremely high resolution, as tolerances are drawn to the nearest 32nd of an inch. Glue and/or sandpaper may be required.  If you like this design, you can donate Bitcoin to 15G6EsYbMQ8jMatCevpYPsmtBQVXBM3hKG. Thanks!

Parts Needed:
  • 1 Arm
  • 1 Axis
  • 1 Basket
  • 1 BasketAttachingPin
  • 1 Crossbar
  • 1 Rubber Band (not printed)
  • 1 RubberBandHolderA
  • 1 RubberBandHolderB
  • 2 Side Panels
  • 1 Small Marble (not printed)
  • 2 Spacers
  • 3 SupportAs
  • 1 SupportB
    • Instructions:
  • Hold Side Panels about 3 inches away from each other so that the 2 small feet are on a table and the piece sticking out with the groove is pointing up.
  • Attach your 3 SupportA parts into the 3 vertical slots on each of the side panels so that the cut-out is facing up and the hole is on the lower half.
  • At the same time, attach the SupportB part into the horizontal slot on the lower half of the side panels so that its tongue is on the divots of 2 of the SupportA parts.
  • Make sure all these parts are attached together firmly. Use glue if needed.
  • Put the Axis through the holes in the Side Panels. It should be able to spin freely. If this is not the case, use sandpaper to open the holes more.
  • Slide the Axis out of one Side Panel. Slide the Arm onto the Axis using the second hole from the side with the widened end. The Arm should fit snugly, and when set down should rest on the side of the catapult where 2 SupportA pieces and 1 SupportB piece connect, ready to be loaded.
  • Connect a Spacer onto each end of the Axis. They should fit snugly and prevent the Axis from falling off of the assembly. Again, use glue if needed.
  • Connect RubberBandHolderA through the hole on the Arm closest to the hole through which the Axis is connected. It should fit snugly and stick out of each end of the Arm.
  • Connect RubberBandHolderB through the holes on the 2 SupportA pieces connected to the SupportB piece. It should stick out of the back of the assembly just under 1/2 of an inch.
  • Slide the Crossbar into the slots on the top of the catapult. It should fit snugly and prevent the Arm from falling completely forward.
  • Attach the Basket to the Arm with the BasketAttachingPin.
  • The catapult is assembled. Attach a rubber band onto the end of RubberBandHolderB sticking out of the back of the catapult, and run it under the assembly. Run it under and back over each side of RubberBandHolderA, finally connecting it to one of the tongues on the Arm. See the uploaded photos for more information.

This is a peristaltic pump we created during Futurelabcamp Boston. It uses a NEMA 14 stepper motor to drive the rotational pump. The stepper motor driver is based on the standard design of L297/L298. We use an arduino to step it. It has it's own website on http://peristalsis.tentacleriot.eu

title: Battery Crash Casing for Warthox Quadcopter Frames

description.text:
Want some protection for your highly flamable and potentially explosive LiPo battery when your quadcopter crashes? You're in luck! Having dented a couple of my batteries from making emergency landings from several meters from the ground, I decided this fragile part of the quadcopter needed a bit more protection. This is a rigid casing for batteries sized up to 25mm x 50mm x 150mm. Designed to fit flush over the screws of a Warthox Quadcopter frame and attached with long strips of velcro to the frame. Using a 0.5mm nozzle with a 0.2mm layer height and 280-300% extrusion width, the total weight of the case came up to about 100 grams. Bit heavy, but lots of protection for the battery. Also, the triangles at the sides allows you to attach these landing legs to the casing. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:89154 The frame it's designed for; http://flyduino.net/Quadrocopter-Frame-Set-20cm-arm
The battery it's designed for; http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__9957__ZIPPY_Flightmax_4000mAh_3S1P_40C.html

Print the case vertically.  
I'd use a higher than normal extrusion width, or at least increase the extrusion multiplier to 1.1 or 1.2, so that each layer is fused to the other more firmly. It wouldn't be the prettiest result, but it'll be stronger.  
I used a hexagonal infill at 50%, to save on weight, you might get away with less, but I wouldn't push it too far if you're planning on crashing a lot.  
When you're done, simply thread the velcro straps through the supplied gaps horizontally and vertically and make sure it doesn't wiggle around too much.  
If your battery rattles around in the case, I would recommend padding it with some foam or bubble wrap.  
After several hard landings onto concrete, my case delaminated along the layers, I was using PLA, maybe it'll be a bit more impact resistant with ABS or Nylon.

This thing presents both Scalar M and Scalar XL 3D printers. Scalar Family 3D printers are "scalable" printers.
Reviewing the idea of a reprap printer, a printer that can auto replicate and scale, we wanted to propose a 3D printer with plastic parts for you to print, and with a way to "scale" easily. That's why we used 30x30 aluminum extrusion profiles as a base because:
  • It's robust
  • It's easy to find
  • It's standard
  • It's lightweight, afterall it's alumunum ;)
  • It's rigid!
  • It's easy to screw
  • Many standard accessory parts already exist in metal such as metal brackets, supports etc....
  • It's cheap.

Mainly all technical information can be found on our website:
http://3dmodularsystems.com But here is a summary of the main characteristics :

• Medium build platform: 200x300mm heat-bed
  • 12V 240w silicon heat-bed with a 3mm aluminum print surface
  • AluHotEnd V7 semi metal hot end as default with 0.4mm nozzle
  • Built-in blower fan
  • Built-in LCD and SD card support
  • Built-in spool holder
  • 360W 12V industrial power supply
  • Inductive probe for bed leveling
  • built in tensioner
  • Plastic parts available for different hot ends: E3D, AluHotEnd and Prometheus V1.1.
  • Can be upgraded into Scalar XL printer

• Big build platform: 400x300mm heat-bed
  • 220V 700w silicon heat-bed with a 3mm aluminum print surface.
  • E3D V6 fullmetal hot end as default with 0.6mm nozzle
  • Built-in blower fan
  • Built-in LCD and SD card support
  • Built-in spool holder
  • 360W 12V industrial power supply for electronics
  • Inductive probe for bed leveling
  • built in tensioner
  • Plastic parts available for different hot ends: E3D, AluHotEnd and Prometheus V1.1.
  • Can be downgraded into Scalar M printer

Because you guys have different ways of life, events happening and so on, we wanted to make sure that those printers can be scaled by only adding the necessary parts to upgrade/downgrade your printers.
This way whenever you want the printer to be bigger or smaller (who knows !) then we have a kit for that:
We already have 2 expansion kits that we will release after the Kickstarter campaign:
  • 1 Upgrade kit to convert a Scalar M into Scalar XL printer
  • 1 Downgrade kit to convert a Scalar XL into Scalar M printer.
    • And we are also working on a "boxed" version of each model, and of course an upgrade kit for each so that you can go from any Scalar family 3D printer into the "boxed" version of it without buying a new printer. Just reuse the parts you already have and add what is missing.

• The full Scalar M and Scalar XL kits are now available on on our website:
    http://3dmodularsystems.com

Scalar M:
  • 6x 400mm 3030 aluminum extrusion
  • 1x 500mm 3030 aluminum extrusion
  • 6x8mm Smooth rod 435mm long
  • 2x 435mm 8mm threaded rod
    • Scalar XL:
  • 2x 400mm 3030 aluminum extrusion
  • 2x 500mm 3030 aluminum extrusion
  • 2x 600mm 3030 aluminum extrusion
  • 1x 700mm 3030 aluminum extrusion

comments.author: chrisdruckt

comments.text:
we are using Bosh type, but i guess Item type should do, the nuts will be different however.
We managed to print 60x60cm, but you need to consider re-inforcing your heatbed and probably the Z Axis to prevent vibrations.
Also you need to make some adjustments if you want to use normal belts, they will vibrate at these length. Consider using Helix screws instead or anything other than belts.

comments.text:
​I have a couple of questions to be cleared about wiring. First of all, as I understood from @mickeypop 's sayings in here:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Enable-Auto-Leveling-for-your-3D-Printer-Marlin-Fi/?ALLSTEPS , S pin of the RAMPS is "Signal in" pin and it needs to take in 5V voltage. PNP and NPN proximity sensors are different basically as the Black wire could be used as "sinking" or "sourcing" the current as mentioned here:
http://www.schneider-electric.co.uk/en/faqs/FA142566/
comments.author: s3rkan

comments.text:
We are using NPN inductive probes and we are using either a 5V version of the probe ( http://3dmodularsystems.com/en/eletronic-components/203-inductive-probe-5v-lj12a3-4-zbx-5v.html ) or this diagram:
http://doc.3dmodularsystems.com/lj12a3-4-zbx-inductive-probe-wiring/
comments.author: s3rkan

the left side, right after the resistors

On the firmware side you need to activate this LCD model inside configuration.h
Also you might require some arduino lib for this display.
The procedure on where to find this library and how to install it is descried inside configuration.h of the firmware.

Placing the motors are the top may be a good idea, we thought about an upgrade like this but never really made anything out of this.
Add a bearing is a bad idead, because it will just amplify the wooble effect and directly impact your printed object.
I believe we can reduce the wooble by choosing the proper coupler model, the ones with the holding screws on the side my be better than the one with the holding screws in the center of the coupler.
It's just a hint, nothing certain yet.

Hello!
Indeed, we removed it because if you are using simple M8 threaded rod you will generate wooble.
At first it seems a good idea but M8 threaded rods are never really straight. If you are using Trapezoidal screw however it can have some meaning.
Adding a constraint at the top of a curved threaded rod will cause a nasty finish on the shell of your prints.(wooble effect).

description.text: If you like my stuff, Please do follow me :)
A replacement speedboat kill cord clip.

Case for mounting an Arduino and a HC-SR04 distance sensor to control a height adjustable table using proximity.
Modeled to fit a SainSmart Arduino UNO. INSTRUCTABLE available here
http://www.instructables.com/id/Force-Table-Distance-controller-for-height-adjusta/ https://youtu.be/AR2-vTPq5gI

Bumper for bottom of toilet seat.  It's parametric, so it will fit any toilet seat hole pattern, hole size/depth, or bumper thickness.   Print it in Ninjaflex or other "soft" filament for the best noise-damping results.

I printed these in Ninjaflex Clear, on a K8200 on blue tape.  I rubbed my dirty, slightly oily fingers on the tape, otherwise the Ninjaflex has a tendency to pick up the top layer of tape.   DO NOT PRINT NINJAFLEX ON AN UNPROTECTED BED!  IT MAY STICK SO HARD IT WILL RUIN THE BED.  (D A M H I K).   
Print at minimal fill (10-20% hexagons) for maximum cushioning and seat drop quieting, or higher (30-40%) for greater stiffness and durability, and three or four perimeter loops.  
I found that, for Ninjaflex, a square post with the corners trimmed by wirecutters just to fit inserted far more easily than circular posts, and holds just fine, even when abused by preschoolers.   
You can vary the bumper thickness, hole pattern, depth, and post size to suit your particular toilet seat.   Just open the file in OpenSCAD (GPLed open source), make your changes, export as STL, slice, and print.   
When you install the bumpers, a bit of wet soap + water on the posts makes them insert much more easily yet retention is still excellent.  
I would have included an "as installed" photo, but the toilet needed cleaning and the photo was just too disgusting for publication.   We don't need another tubgirl, folks....

title: Spacer set for ZMR250 (bottom mounted LiPo)

description.text:
Yep.. another one.
Customized mostly for my own setup, but others may find it useful. The front and rear spacer are the same. They're shaped to provide a little extra space, in my case to stick a D4R-II between the center plates. They're slightly angled down to increase visibility while in flight above you. Stick the lights on there with double sided tape. The arm spacers are 9mm and give you a total of 12mm between the center plates. There's an extra spacer with integrated XT60 mount. It's a bit tricky to use I guess, here's how:
The small plate is glued on the bottom of the XT60 (angled edges facing left) with a bit of superglue. The ridges are meant to fit into the logo part of the plug.
The spacer part also gets a drop of glue. Screw the frame together loosely, then adjust plug position until it too slips into the ridges on the other side. Tighten the frame down and the plug will be securely held in place. The plastic plug should not be visibly deformed, otherwise the ridges are not in the right place.
Lightly squeeze the plug prongs with pliers if needed if they are too tight. Note that this will only work if you have the LiPo at the bottom, from the top, the power wires will get into the way of the propellers! Some of the parts are loosely based on other people's STLs, but since I started working on them months ago already, I no longer know whose. If you know, I'll happily add the source.

remixed_from.title: Parametric pulley - lots of tooth profiles

description.text:
This is the Keep-It-Simple-Stupid Robotic Arm. It was designed to have as little wobble as possible and uses no special hardware. All driving motors are usual NEMA17 steppers, the controlling part is based on a RAMPS board running on unmodified Sprinter firmware ( https://github.com/kliment/Sprinter ), but this is temporary. Also, most connections are inspired by the NEMA17 design and can be combined in any configuration that is neccessary. The design was inspired by KUKA industrial arms and by a KSP mod called B9 Aerospace (HX module family specifically). Video:
https://youtu.be/2qWauCi74jA

WARNING:
Many STLs are not split. Split them before printing and align correctly for good printing. All screws and nuts used are M3. Most connections are based on the NEMA17 design, so one connection block is 42 mm x 42 mm, with a 25 mm hole in the center and distance between screws 31 mm. Spacers of various sizes, straight and angle connectors are available. There are three types of hinges:
  • Direct-driven smaller hinge
  • Bigger hinge with a reducer
  • Direct-driven rotating connector
  • Big rotating base (still working on it!)
    • The smaller hinge has its axis aligned with the NEMA17 rotation axis. One side of the hinge is connected to the motor shaft and the other rotates on a 608ZZ bearing. To hold all the pieces together the static part (which holds the motor) and the moving part must be connected to spacers or longer connectors. The bigger hinge uses two geared slew bearings (thanks emmett) and is driven by a stepper with a 14-tooth pulley through a T2.5 timing belt (the resulting ratio is 102:14) and can handle higher loads. Its static side has four connection blocks and the moving side has two. In order to stack them you can use two 2-to-1 connectors. To connect two-connector blocks to single-connector ones use 2-to-1 connectors. The 42 mm rotating connector uses the motor shaft as the only part that connects the two sides of it. See photos. Now the new rotating base. It uses a bigger gear bearing for more stability. It is not yet tested, but feel free to try it!

UPDATE 2
Designed a folding post so your print area should be only minimally effected by this add-on. Moving the bed to the bottom deploys the post and after using the post to deploy and retract the probe, you can retract the post by pushing it up slightly.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJsdiVgMl-8 UPDATE!! Changed parts so they lock more securely by moving the magnet up. I also changed my post setup so it is actually screwed into the platform, as opposed to using a binder clip. Will upload better pictures of the post (thing used to switch the probe up/down) soon. It's way more stable now, but the attachment to the print head is still not optimal. This is a Z-probe mount for ultimaker! It uses a pushbutton switch to attach your min z endstop to your head! A simple printhead motion lowers and raises the probe to allow fully automated platform sensing and printing. Never worry about getting the perfect z-height again! Video here http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a-A90wP4Wus Or maybe do because this thing doesn't work perfectly. WIP!

Use two 2mm cube-shaped neodymium magnets; they get glued into the little square spots in "swivelmount.stl".  
For the bearing I used a standard little bearing that you can get out of most hard drives. 9.5mm OD, 6.35mm ID, 3.17mm thickness.  
I used a momentary push button switch with a lever arm similar to what the ultimaker uses normally (you could probably just take off the z min endstop and mount it on this thing; the holes may not be correct though).  A screw placed in the medium sized hole in "swingarm" acts as a target for magnet attraction. Adding some nuts on that screw also helps as they have flat faces that increase attraction.  
The swivelmount attaches to the print head using the same screws as hold the printhead together; substitute them with slightly longer screws to attach the part.  
Finally, route some flexible wire to connect to the switch. This part I haven't completely figured out how to do properly; the attachment of the wires does matter because the wires exert a slight force on the lever arm; you want the force helping to push the arm DOWN.  
The last part which I have not yet designed is a little post that the ultimaker will use to raise/lower the sensor. I bent a piece of wire and attached that to the platform using a binder clip.  
The procedure for leveling goes like this: Home the platform to the bottom of the printer. Either reprogram your marlin install to home to max or tell the bed to go to +1000 with endstops enabled. Then, raise the bed up so the switching post is at the correct level to switch the lever arm. Move the head so the lever arm switches down, then move to the middle and slowly raise the bed. Since you enabled endstops during moves (you did, right?) the platform should stop as if it has reached the max endstop when it clicks the button. This may take some fiddling as if you don't have a good metal part to hold the lever arm to the magnet with, it might pop off during this process. WATCH YOUR PRINTER LIKE A HAWK during the first few tries. Once you manage to get it repeatable it should be ok, but again this is WIP so it can probably use some re-designing.   
Anyway just watch the video if this is confusing.

comments.text:
This is quite clever so as not to require a heavy actuator nor any firmware tweaks (I did not check enough the first time I "liked" this)...
Hey, with a set of N latched levers moved by the head you could program 2^N fully firmware-independent behaviors :D

comments.text: I use a gcode post processor plugin to adjust te Z height, I ussually adjust like 0.24mm or so. This probe would only be useful (in my opinion) if its deviation is less or equal to the thickness of the best Z-resolution of the printer. Which is 0.02mm for an ultimaker if I am informed correctly. I am having a hard time believing that a self made construction would make the adjustment of Z in GCODE obsolete.
comments.author: mikedeklerk

comments.text: You are assuming that your platform is at the same z-height every time, which, with the standard ultimaker z-assembly, is not the case. After scraping off your part, even if you are not using a heated platform, you have jostled the platform enough that it will definitely be more than 0.02mm off. I have not measured the repeatability with this system, but since I have put it in, my first layers have been perfect every time. Before, it was hit or miss.

comments.author: destroyer2012

comments.text: I think the non-repeatability is due to wood or platform riser expansion. In my experience, the first print from cold is fine, but if you keep the bed hot and try printing again you begin to start too low, either because the bed rises when it heats up or the wooden frame shrinks from losing moisture. By probing the bed each time it's unlikely that you will observe these influences.
comments.author: Doxin

comments.text: I haven't got a hotbed, so I doubt that that's the problem. it might be the cantilever having some play though, which this would prevent.

title: Print Metal - AirVortex3D is an attachment that dries metal clay (BRONZclay3D) soon after extrusion so tall objects can be printed with metal clay. Once the clay is dried, it is fired in an inexpensive kiln to a solid bronze object.

description.text: The AirVortex3D solves the problem of slumping when printing with metal clay or other paste-like materials. The BRONZclay3D is a mix of bronze powder (90% Copper, 10% Tin), water, binder and other non-toxic materials. Once fired, the bronze sinters into a solid metal object that has the same properties as cast bronze. It malleable, drillable, and has all of the properties you would expect with bronze metal. When polished it looks similar to 18K gold. The AirVortex3D is shown attached to the Mini Metal Maker. The collapsed cylinder shown are printing without the AirVortex3D turned on. One photo shows 3 cylinders, first has no air and no heat, second shows air with no heat, and the third shows what the AirVortex3D can produce with air and heat.

The AirVortex3D was printed on an UP! with no raft, and has rare earth magnets that hold it to the Mini Metal Maker printer. The blower is a 12 volt 2 watt Sunon maglev GB1205PHVX-8AY the halogen lamp is 12 volt 5 watt with a G4 base, and mounted on the ceramic G4 lamp holder. The blower is super glued to the AirVortex3D, and the lamp holder fits by friction. Note that a 10 watt lamp gives too much heat causing the nozzle to clog. With a 5 watt, there is about a 5 degree C rise in the exit temperature which dries the clay soon after extrusion. The blower is mounted so that the warm air exiting swirls at about 70 RPM allowing drying without distortion of the clay.

description.text: Smooth rounded well fitted stand for the Samsung Gear S smartwatch.
I had to drill the holes in the base a little. But that may just be my printer (this is the first thing I have designed and only the 2nd thing I ever printed)

comments.text:
Just printed my second one of these, one for home and one for travel. I too had to ream the pin holes on the base to effect a fit. I tried to angle the stem back a bit but my 3D model editing skills aren't there yet. This would allow a better viewing angle.
This stand has turned out to be real winner as the little "L" shaped connectors on the back of the charger that snap into the watch are very delicate and break off in short order. I'm on my third charger already. Now I've glued the charger to the stand and bracelet compression holds it in place for charging taking the connectors out of the equation.
Now if anyone has a simple way to get a printed object off the Lulzbot mini hot bed that doesn't include barking your fingers, I'd be very interested. BTW, the compressed air cooling suggestion doesn't work..
Thanks for this design.

title: Quadcopter Landing Legs with Camera Mount for Battery Crash Case

description.text: These are landing legs for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:89140 The camera mount should be able to mount most cameras up to 100mm wide. If you don't have the screw required to attach the camera to the mount, velcro would be an option as well.

I'd use a higher than normal extrusion width, or at least increase the extrusion multiplier to 1.1 or 1.2, so that each layer is fused to the other more firmly. It wouldn't be the prettiest result, but it'll be stronger.  
I used a hexagonal infill at 50%, to save on weight, you might get away with less, but I wouldn't push it too far if you're planning on crashing a lot.  
Use M3 screws and nuts to connect it to the battery case.

title: Sunhokey 2015 Prusa i3 Nozzle Fan/Nozzle Fan Holder

description.text:
Modified nozzle fan holder set for Sunhokey 2015 Prusa i3, derived/revised from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:714939
And modified LCD Frame Casing for mounting onto the top of the Acrylic Frame from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:797839

My version of Sunhokey 2015 Prusa i3 came without a Nozzle fan, I've modified ZiegeOne's version to be able to mount the fan to the new version and to be fixed with the spare parts that were supplied with the DIY 3d printer. For instructions please head to instructables. Search for "Sunhokey 2015 Prusa i3 DIY Kit". Included is also the modified version of axokill's LCD Frame casing for mounting onto the top of the acrylic frame. (Choose from Front/Back Facing, mine is back facing, accidentally)

comments.text:
on which pins you connect the fan??
and one a Another question on the bed and extruder which temperature you print PLA and what speed???
(i am noob in the 3d printing)
and thx for the files
comments.author: JonathanNL

comments.text:
The same pins that you use to connect the extruder (the one constantly blowing onto the heat sink) fan.
https://cdn.hackaday.io/images/7023531457473700487.png
Number 4 in the picture.
For PLA, it is recommended by the vendor at least 220 deg for the extruder and 50 deg for the bed, especially if you're using the filament that came with the kit, however I am using ABS, and printing at 265 deg for the extruder(AFTER swapping out the PTFE liner nozzle throat with an all metal one) and 90 deg for the bed.
As for speed, you can follow what the vendor has shown in the video, in Repitier Host for Cura set 30mm/s for everything except travel which is at 100mm/s, that will give you nice prints albiet at a slower speed, however if you are more interested in faster print with ok quality, use Slic3r, and follow the default settings that the vendor has recommended.
comments.author: JonathanNL

comments.text: This looks very interesting and im just about to do it but, could you please compare your experience before and after the upgrade?
comments.author: Silver1992

comments.text: I answer myself. Just finished installing the pieces. What I notice is that the fan that keeps the melt chamber cool crates air drafts that also cools the nozzle. I previously removed the 3D printed supports Sunhokey provided, to avoid this happening. As a result, the nozzle takes takes a bit longer to heat and present too much oscilating temps.

2 - 8mm Stainless Steel Rods This y-axis switch holder mounts under the aluminum bearing.

I used
4 - M3 bolts
4 - M3 Nuts

4 - SCS8UU Linear Motion Ball Bearing CNC Slide Bushing
2 - 8mm Stainless Steel Rods This y-axis switch holder mounts under the aluminum bearing. You have to slide 4 M3 nuts into the side holes and then use a long M3 bolt. title: Wind Turbine Concept - HMS Windy One
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
This is my concept of wind turbine. i was inspired from this link to build my own one.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:139193
originally. My plan was to publish this design when I finished it almost but there is a challenge now. So I start to add the design to thingiverse now. So, my Basic ideas was:
  • build all all parts on 200x200x180mm
  • use a Nema 17 Motor (spare of my printer) as Generator. another motor should be possible
  • storm safety
  • basic design should have a gearing
  • not too much different bolt sizes
  • less overall / single print times
  • adjustable on different locations -> wind speed
  • strong enough design
  • load a 12V battery
    • I tried the turbine from the link above but it doesn´t work for me well. My problem was that I have the most time less wind speed -> I think not more than 3m/s (I can´t say how much clearly, I haven’t a anemometer…). So I decided to generate my own propeller by 2 arguments. Too less wind speed and the print time for 1 propeller blade (12h+). You can see the version of this on the last picture. (3 blades with the green generator house). But in the end now. I not happy with this solution and still it doesn’t generate enough to load a 12V battery. I made a Voltage double with after the stepper motor.
    http://www.reuk.co.uk/Stepper-Motor-Voltage-Doubler-Circuit.htm
    At this point, I Sayed: I create my own complete design. (this was approx. before 1 month). My basic design is almost finish now. I need to do some details. Now. I need to print and test. But this will take time. ~2 weeks up to now.
    I tried to make it so much expandable and adjustable as possible. To my design now:
  • 4 blades – can be extended up to 12 (like western mill) or maybe 2 bigger one but this is not considered by me. Angle of attack can be adjusted.
  • Adjustable gear: standard gear ratio of 1:1,7 up to 3 times. I will try with 3 times of this (i´m not an expert with gears. Pls correct my when I write something wrong)
  • The complete set with gear and motor can be completely removed for maintain or repair.
  • I made a storm regulation with a counterweight and 2 flags. Common used solution for DIY design up to 9m diameter. Hopefully it will work for my.
  • Most used bolts M4x30, Main shaft M8 threaded rod, flags rod M6, fixing diameter on the bottom 22mm
  • Diameter can be made in 950mm or 1350mm. flag distance can be adjusted acc this but is generally design for the larger diameter.
    • General. I used in my design a printed thread, gear, screw connection,… The blade design is simple. A flat design is faster to print and get a smoother surface if you have a heatbed. Instead of print it vertical up with rotation. Instructions, pls download the PDF guide. i´m almost finished now. the Propeller is rotating. the small Nema 17 Motor generates 12V (see picture). it´s is stable. wonderfull :)
    The Motor is not the best, for sure if someone find a good cheap geneator, it will be a lot better then the NEMA 17. space is enough to bring it in. holes are also prepared for Expansion of Motor and gearing. one alternative ieda is also to use belts instead of gearings. i have also uplaoded a Video.
    https://youtu.be/hAoowl3r-Ps in the end, i Need to thanks my father for his Support, it was a nice summer project. best regards
    Semml The End 02.08.2015 Update
    print is ongoing. i have created some Detail Pictures of the design and uploaded it now. i found on more weak Point and it will be updated (Fixing of the blade to the round part) - 27.06.2015
    Update
    print process is slowed down because of the makeitfloat challenge. but we assemblied a few components now. i have a small issue at the Moment with the noise of the gearing. i try to make a gear set.
    potho added. - 02.07.2015
    Update
    i have uploaded a few files now because of user comments :)
    this includes a stronger main blade and Support (Support is sometimes broken when thighten the bolts). Propeller and cone for it is also included. the Propeller is designed to mount on a M8 threaded rod
    i hope i can finish it in time because my Printer is broken over the Weekend.
    Basic instruction added - 14.07.2015
    Update
    Basic instruction deleted, Instruction PDF uploaded. first draft!!!
    Video added.
    printing is ongoing, hopefully in time :/
    https://youtu.be/Uc-YiuEondI
    End - 30.07.2015
    Update
    it was a good and bad day today. good: i have assemblied a lot. bad: no wind for test. :/
    some improvments discovered. hopefully i can print it tomorrow
    new Picture uploaded with the most stuff assemblied. i will try to finish the storm Regulation tomorrow.
    End - 31.07.2015
    Update 1
    STL Files uploaded in the zip file. (includes file structure for better understanding). the stl files wich i have uploaded thill now, are the same as in the zip file.
    new set of PDF Drawing uploaded with the latest model.
    DWG file of my gearing.
    Ende - 02.08.2015
    Update 2
    Video uploaded,.
    Instructions uploaded
    Description modifications
    End - 02.08.2015

Please download and look into the instruction PDF.  i prepared a lot of Picture and guides. it is more easy to use the PDF insted to write everthing here.  
thanks

title: Replacement Nose Pad for Oakley Sunglasses

description.text:
I lost one of the nose pads for my favorite pair of sunglasses so I designed a replacement.  The nose pad includes the dimple for the sunglasses to securely grip the pad.  
Best results have been on the SLA Form 1+ I have access to.  The detail level of my Printrbot has not been good enough for me liking on this part.

I took rough measurements from the remaining nose pad, then modeled it in 123D Design.  After Ia few iterations I was happy with the design.  I've been using it for over 6 months now.  
Printing in clear or gray works well. A clear flexible resin would be ideal, but I don't have that yet.

description.text:
This is my modular lighting system. It is based on a joint and a tower structure. It can build in various forms. I decides to build a star Like structure. I use LED disks with an WS2811 controller and 6 rgb leds with a diameter of about 40mm. As white light I use 50mm disk leds. Mounted on a 70mm heatsink. I used 12mm Aluminium tubes for the cables.
To control the leds I used a sparkcore, but for future use I recommend an esp866 module. I post more detailed assembly information soon. I added a demo scetch and a new video with more details.
https://youtu.be/UsbwFbMxnlg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UPnAon349_Y

title: Cheap and Easy Prusa Spool Holder

description.text:
Needed a spool holder that didn't take a lot of parts.  This one needs either 4 M8 bolts or 2 M8 threaded rods (with 4 nuts), 4 bearings, 8 washers and 4 fender washers.
Designed to fit the Ultimachine PLA spools, so I have no idea if it will work for anything else.
Note: pictures to follow (need to find the camera), also, you'll need 2.
Assemble, place on the top bars, print without so much handholding.

comments.text: Simple and effective. I'm actually using them without bearings. I just used two leftover pieces of smooth rod I had left. Space them far enough apart that the spool catches the holder and doesn't fall off.

Works quite well, however, sometimes the filament is drawn enough that when the X motor goes in the other direction, the filament may "jump off" the spool (if that makes sense). I guess this is more of a problem when the spool is new and there isn't much of an edge to keep the filament on the spool itself. The 4b object has some thinning of the base part. Not printed yet, but might help the retraction into the handle. The part is not perfect, but helps stop broken junk from landing in the "garbage". I hate throwing stuff away.

I had to sand the "nubs" on the arms round to make it go smoothly.
Tried printing this on the flat, and failed. Printed it on the side as shown, and it worked ok.

description.text: Mount to adapt a 12VDC 30A power supply (e.g. 12v 30a Dc Universal Regulated Switching Power Supply 360w for CCTV, Radio, Computer Project) to the 3uP.

In addition to a power supply with similar mounting requirements and the mounts, you will need the following: 2 x M4*8mm Button Head Hex Socket Cap Screws
2 x M4*10mm Button Head Hex Socket Cap Screws
2 x M5*10mm Hex Socket Cap Screws
2 x M5 T-slot Nuts Attach the countersunk screws to the power supply body with the shorter screws, and use the longer screws for the other side of the mount. Be aware that you will have to move the two T-slot nuts to the inside edge of the extrusion rail, rather than the default top edge position. Ream out the M5 holes with a 13/64" drill bit. File the extrusion slot to fit snugly, if necessary. Pay very close attention to the labeling when connecting input and output power connections, commodity power supplies often switch arrangements without notice. Also, be mindful of the input power switch! Most of these power supplies ship in the 220 AC input configuration. Be sure to check (and double-check) the setting before power-on!

This is my entry for the #CatchTheWind contest. This is a windmill that has a 11 to 1 gear reduction to enable you to do things that you just can't do without gearing. Things like pump water, power complicated whirligigs with many moving parts, or anything else you can imagine! This one will power a rock tumbler when it is finished. My wife doesn't want a rock tumbler in the house because of the noise so this will have a home in the corner of the yard closest to my most annoying neighbor. Please take the time to Like this for the contest. Here is a video of it https://youtu.be/Q1OcJvvggyc

All parts print flat without support. Stack the blade parts on threaded rod and tighten them together. They align themselves and lock into position. 608 skate bearings are used on either side of the gear plates to ensure smooth movement. The rock tumbling grit will simply be various grits of sandpaper cut into small pieces and a cup of water. Start with a coarse 100 grit and finish with a very fine 1000 grit. There is no need to buy the very expensive commercial grits available for rock tumblers. The paper gets pounded into nothing by the rocks and the grit ends up in solution to polish the rocks. Enjoy the build! Final assembly complete. Pardon the mix of measurements, I get imperial hardware cheap but I think in metric.
  • 1 threaded 5/16th inch rod 410mm long (blade drive)
  • 1 threaded 5/16th inch rod 314 mm long (tumbler drive)
  • 2 threaded 5/16th inch rods 212mm long (bottom supports)
    (vary rod length for taller or shorter jar)
  • 1 jar 150mm high 90 mm diameter (spaghetti sauce)
  • 1 5/16 inch bolt 50 mm long (or a section of rod for idler gear)
  • 2 large washers 36mm in diameter or larger to keep jar centered
  • 1 bolt 5/16 for tumble jar 55.5 mm overall length
  • 2 nuts and bolts 2mm for fins (anything will work drill for what you got)
  • 2 rubber grommets or sections of rubber tube forced onto drive rod.
  • 16 skate bearings (608)
  • 26 5/16 inch nuts

  • 14 small washers

    This was modeled in Sketchup. The files were converted to STL format using the SketchUp STL plugin. The files were checked for manifold errors using the Solid Inspector plugin. And the files were cleaned with the Cleanup plugin during construction. All parts were printed on my RepStrap Monkey S#t Fight and will print on any 200 200 mm bed. I used PLA with 3 shells and %40 rectilinear infill for all parts.

    Assemble as shown in the pictures and mount on a pivot using the frame pivot tube. A glass marble on top of a stick makes a decent pivot. Mount in a windy location and enjoy your shiny new rocks in a couple weeks!

title: Bosch Random Orbital Sander Dust Shroud

description.text:
This part improves dust collection with 5" BOSCH Random Orbital Sanders. It is meant to prevent particles from being ejected away from the sander. It is also meant to increase the airflow speed at the perimeter of the work area to remove a larger number of particles. For good dust control, use wet sanding with a HEPA vacuum. The dust shroud is compatible with the following Bosch random orbital sanders:
  • ROS10 (3601C8P7010) 5" Palm-Grip Random Orbit Sander
  • ROS20VS (3601C87511) 5" Variable Speed Palm-Grip Random Orbit Sander Kit
  • ROS20VSK (3601C87511) 5 in. Variable Speed Palm-Grip Random Orbit Sander
    • The dust shroud replaces the sander's Friction Ring 2609170071 (http://www.ereplacementparts.com/friction-ring-p-163180.html).

The part must be flexible and resilient to conform to the work surface. Print the shroud using Taulman PCTPE without supports. To install the shroud:
  • Use a Torx T20 driver to remove the four screws that attach the PSA Pad.
  • Remove the black flexible friction ring.
  • Slide one of the shrouds alignment tabs into one of the sander enclosure's alignment slots. Bend the shroud and slide the second tab into the second slot.
  • Use a spudger or flat screw driver to slide the remainder of the shroud's slot around the sander enclosure's lip.
  • Reattach the PSA Pad.

comments.text:
Die Frage zur Ansteuerung und wie gehts weiter:
Also das ist nur ein Demo, die Firmware ist noch nicht fertig. Das funktioniert ganz einfach mit einem LED-Player (http://www.led-genial.de/LED-Player-spielt-LED-Effekte-von-SD-Karte-ab). Das kleine Proggy habe ich mit dem beiliegenden LedEddy editiert und auf SD-Karte gespeichert. Das kann man dann Standalone abspielen. Eine Uhr wird dann auf der Basis des "CRONIOS" funktionieren (http://www.led-genial.de/CRONIOS-Elektronik-Platine-fuer-Selberbauer). Das ist eine komplette Uhr mit Ansteuerung für WS2812. Ich denke so im August 2015 sind die PCB für die Digits fertig, wobei auf der Unterseite ein STM32F030 sitzt, der die gesamte WS2812 Steuerung bewerkstelligt. Der könnte dann 25 Stellen treiben. Die Anbindung ist über I2C, ISP z.b. mit Arduino oder RaspPII möglich.

title: Ver.2 GoPro HERO3 mount to suit 450 helis

description.text: This is version 2 of the GoPro HERO3 mount to suit 450PRO helicopters. Ensures a slight downward angle of the lens in hover. Allows for use of velcro to secure camera. Now allows user to glue camera part to mount part on an angle to ensure camera is level during hover.

• Print part 'B' with velcro tabs pointing "UP", raft to prevent warping, 0.2mm layer height, 0.99 scale
  • Print part 'A' with zip-tie holes vertical. Raft to prevent warping, 0.2mm layer height, 0.99 scale
  • On part 'A', use double sided tape under the two "feet", then strap down hard with zip ties through holes onto battery tray.
  • Using superglue or similar, glue part 'B' to part 'A' at an angle of ~3 degrees of leftward tilt. This is to counteract hover tilt on 450 helis
  • Ensure you always secure your camera with velcro by using the designated tabs
    • NOTE: Ensure your glue will hold your expensive camera well enough. Also be careful getting the correct angle of tilt - if you get it right it makes a world of difference to your footage :)

description.text: I may use paper to draw designs on, but reading it while using the laptop, it gets in my way. So i put yet another thing to clamp onto the plank. Works pretty well for me, though i do have to push the paper high enough so it doesnt slide loose too easily.(the paper block has to be thick enough too.) I also needed to use rubber bands to grip it better. None of the tape i had had enough grip, though some did better than the plastic. NOTE: the version i tested had some slicing issue and i added some stuff since it, but i inspected things, so probably it is fine. (feedback appreciated) As usual, development versions at github.

• Check the size of your plank, you could use the .escad file and set your side or use something to pad it up. It works with implicitscad and openscad, with the latter things arent rounded though.

  • Find some elastic bands that arent slippery, and a small)cable tie to hold it down.

  • Print the design.

  • Put the elastic band through the hole one the 'immobile [ad'. hold it down at the top with the cable tie. There are also notches/holes on the other side, but that might not be needed.

  • Try it, check that wobbling it doesnt make stuff slide down and fall. (it shouldnt if you pushed it up far enough.)

On 24 February 2014, Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel directed the Navy to submit alternative proposals for a new surface combatant comparable to a frigate that can operate in all regions under conflict conditions. In response to Pentagon direction to halt LCS purchases at 32 ships, the Navy is re-examining the vessels' role, such a whether they have enough protection and firepower to survive against advanced adversaries, and alternate proposals which included a modified LCS or a new platform. The Navy requires the class' roles of counter-mine, anti-submarine, and surface warfare provided by modules. Proponents point out that the LCS was not designed to function like destroyers but for littoral tasks like high-speed patrols and counter-piracy missions, moving at 40 knots and within shallow water where other ships cannot.

A method of determining optimum print temperature for your filament.  
Now with 0.5 mm Tip, 1.75 mm filament & 0.25 mm Layers

Use slicer with your normal settings, to build G-CODE,
Remember to start at a relativity high temperature, Using Notepad++, or TextPad,
scan through and look for G1 .... X....
at each 5 or 10 mm 'whole number' assuming you print at 0.25 mm for example, and add:
M104 S175 for example will set temperature to 175 Deg. C. I will attempt to post a modified file later. USAGE: Print, and carefully watch for when your filament stops bonding,
or even worse stops extruding. WARNING YOU MUST STOP PRINTING AT THIS POINT !!!!! You can now decode the BINARY BLOCKS, and determine optimum temperature for each filament you own. Enjoy Ceri

Whilst the other pencil designs I have uploaded are attractive enough as art, they lack much practical application. This design spreads the pencils enough for you to insert and replace them easily, displays all of them so you can find the one you are looking for, stays reasonably balanced when you remove a few, accepts differing diameter pencils, hides the sharp ends, and looks reasonably OK if a little utilitarian.  I don't know how well it will function with a mixture of long and short pencils, I suspect that you'll need to place the shorter pencils in the closest holes.

Count your pencils, pick your size and print... I started with PencilsInRows.stl (don't bother printing), but it took an age to slice and > 8 hours to print. I thought to myself, there has to be a better way, so I reduced the plastic to the minimum, reduced the complexity to the minimum, I did slice through the holes diagonally to improve the gcode, but skeinforge didn't understand and got very confused, so I let it work out the tool path for these. The most complex CubeTube81 only takes 2 hours and meets all the usability goals I set myself. I've run out of time to work on these now, but if you'd like to have a go, to make them more stable, I suggest you flip it over and add a flat base that protrudes enough so that you can hold it down when you pull out a pencil. I think I'm done with pencils now...

author: toSvenson

description.text: Cutout scalloped edged cookies sized for perfect dunking. You might also like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:890798 if you liked this one.
Range Wall screwdriver, simple but effective.

A hidden picture lamp, utilizing lithophanes. Note: this does not use an actual hidden picture! It is a piece of plastic where the thicker spots absorb more light (black) and the thinner spots absorb less light (white) giving a photo effect. Lithophane source: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:74322

Less work / More work:
Less: A remix (Remix 1) is included with a single level LED tower. This remix cuts the lamp height in half, and thus reduces the build time. More: Once you are done with developing and printing the lamp there is a Round !! (Yes, Round "double exclamation point"). Cut off the IR remote control sensor and replace it with a WiFi sensor. This will enable you to control the LED strip with your WiFi connected devices, such as your cell phone! Here is a demonstration: https://youtu.be/QEek-LAnwTg

The lamp: (1) Use this website to make the lithophanes: http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=74322 (Note: a few of us could not get this to load in IE; I had to use Chrome). Here is the exact process I used:
  • Image:
    • Picture Shape: Square
    • Picture Orientation: Horizontal
    • Pane Size: Large
    • Invert Colors: Checked
  • Adjustments:
    • Include Hole: No
    • Hole Diameter: [Doesn't apply]
    • Layer Height: 0.2
    • Number of Layers: 20
  • Slicer (KISSlicer to be exact)
    • Height from 4.4mm to 3.2mm
    • If the customizer errors for you, see user "dlee_maker" comment on an alternative lithophane generator. (2) Print your lithophanes and scale to 76 x 76 x 3.2 mm. (Change the print height in your slicer and the x, y dimensions should be correct.) Printing anywhere 0.1mm - 0.2mm is great with 100% infill. (3) I used ABS; the LEDs get the structure up to 50-60C. PLA will work by limiting the LED brightness if it gets much hotter. (4) If you normally use "ABS juice", use a glue stick this time. Cleaning the residual slurry off the flat side will be unsightly (as it is the outside part of the lithophane.) (5) Print the lithophane support structure at your standard settings with no support required. 100% infill is not required for these. (6) The LED tower is glued to the base with something strong such as J-B Weld. (7) The shown LED strip: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B0040FJ27S/ref=sr_ph?ie=UTF8&qid=1434942772&sr=1&keywords=LEDwholesalers Here is a how-to video if you need: https://youtu.be/yYU1c8UoDfI.

The WiFi LED Driver (OPTIONAL!): Materials (for exact copy; substitutes would surely work):
(1) LED Strip + it's power supply (link above) (2) Particle Photon (http://www.particle.io) (3) D24V10F5 Voltage Regulator (http://www.pololu.com) (4) 3 ZTX689B NPN BJTs (http://www.digikey.com)
I highly recommend these transistors over TIP31s that people typically buy. These have a very low saturation current, and they support this power application sufficiently. (5) 3 resistors ~330 ohms (driving this with 3.3V PWMs signals from the Photon) (6) (Optional - Highly Recommended) Heatsinks for the BJTs
Power transistors get hot, and should be used with heatsinks (even TIP31s). With the heatsinks, the transistors measure at ~45C passing 0.4A each. (7) (Optional) Breadboard, Heat-shrink Tubing, Solder (8) (Optional) Web server for Photon to talk to (I'm using a BeagleBone Black.) (9) WiFi Device (Cell Phone, Computer, iPad, etc) There is a photo schematic for how to connect these components. The website's javascript and photon code are fairly straightforward (assuming you have a slightly technical background.) Here is my photon code and a JavaScript example: https://onedrive.live.com/redir?resid=8020F0E348C88BBD!93112&authkey=!AMioGTxVfcdw1gA&ithint=file%2ctxt [Update: 10/25/2015 - Be sure to use pull down resistors on the base of each transistor. Just use ~10k ohm resistors on each base to the ground.]

comments.author: kevinbragg

comments.text: In the instructions I mentioned using ABS because my temperature gun said the lid of the lamp was at ~62C.  That's right around the PLA heated-bed temperature... a little close for comfort.  I didn't want the lithophanes to deform under constant exposure to heat.  So I suggest a higher temperature plastic.  I did go through many iterations to get just the right size (also mentioned) because of warping... obviously the panes cant warp or it'll look terrible.  I run my heated bed at 107C and used the purple glue stick.  Normally I print on abs slurry... but I wanted smooth surfaces for a nice outside appearance.  That meant purple glue stick, and "smaller" panes.
comments.author: Veerix

comments.text: Okay thanks Kevin! I'm using a CubePro Trio, so the build plate isn't heated, instead the enclosed chamber is when printing in ABS. Might take a few tries to get the panes to come out just right as it looks like you had to go through yourself. Anyways, you're final product looks amazing.
comments.author: kevinbragg

comments.text: The strip I suggested also lets you turn down the intensity.  If you make your layers thinner than 3.2mm... say 77 x 77 x 1.8 they'll give you similar illumination at lower power.  The only negative is thinner lithophanes is less discrete levels to absorb light.  But I bet if you use 1.8mm and turn the LED strip down, you'd be able to run in the 40-50C range and have no PLA issues.  You could also just put a hole in the top of the structure to vent the heat... that would work too, lol (but with light leaking).
comments.author: Veerix

comments.text: Just use multiple layers of porch door screen. Then you don't have to adjust anything and the light can be modified/amplified to the patterns of your lithopone panels. It also will reduce light escaping without hindering the functionality.

remixed_from.author: ericskiff
remixed_from.title: Laptop Stand with steampunk gear design

description.text:
My mom needed a laptop stand so I decided to make this for her Birthday tomorrow. I really like how it came out and I love the interaction of the wave and the wood grain. My process went something like this:
My mom's always liked Japanese prints (she grew up in Japan) and so I knew I wanted to do a Hokusai wave. I found a creative commons image (http://nickpoint.files.wordpress.com/2008/12/the_great_wave_off_kanagawa.jpg) and imported it into Gimp. I adjusted the levels and threshold-ed it to make it just black and white. From there I played with it a bit in Inkscape using the trace bitmap tool. Eventually I ended up with what you see there.
I had a little bit of trouble with some text that I put on the bottom connector but I got it to work after I converted it to a path and exploded it.

comments.text: Thanks for the lovely derived art!  I just cut one of these and I'm using it now :)  I had to add a little curve at the top to accomodate the curve on the bottom of my 11" MacBook Air (it was sliding off).  But otherwise, superb!

title: USB Powered Printer Lighting for Lulzbot Mini (or others) Using Eveready LED Flashlight

description.text: I have many Eveready 6v flashlights because the price of a battery/flashlight combo ($4.97), is only 29 cents more than the cost of a battery alone ($4.68) at my local Home Depot (FN1). It's really hard to force myself to not buy the combo even though I've got these things coming out my ears by now and I almost always break down and just buy the combo. I've finally found a use for some of my dead flashlights: cheap lighting for my printer! Basically, for 29 cents I get some LEDs and resistors soldered to a board already drilled with mounting holes, a button, and an unbreakable beer mug (not really of course, I doubt the plastic is food grade). The only other non-printed part needed is one of the many now useless mini-USB cords I have sitting in a box because nothing uses those anymore. I've uploaded the files in STL and FreeCAD native file format. If you don't have a printer like mine, but do have a stack of these flashlights, I've also included just the button mount for the Eveready button which you can attach to something made for your printer. When printed sideways with the supports in place, the button fits in nice and snug because of the fine bits of support material left over -- you could get away with using no glue to hold it in place. If printed on its back, no support is needed, but you'll probably need glue or epoxy. My example is printed in natural ABS on a Lulzbot Mini, Cura basic settings, normal (med) quality. --- assembly instructions (FN2) --- Removing the LED board: the first thing to do is grab the large conductive ring at the base of the flashilight head, cut through the plastic supports and attachment bits, and break that off. The board isn't screwed down -- instead little melted plastic posts hold it in place. A few snips will allow you to wiggle it free. You'll see where positive and negative get attached -- take a mental note and clip off the positive wire (negative is just a contact spring). Removing the button: the button is held in place by friction, not a nut. First, remove the rubber weather boot by pulling it off (again, not screwed down). Then, using a flathead screwdriver or something similar, from the inside of the flahslight body pry the switch body down through the hole. It kind of helps to pry along the vertical walls too. You can also try pounding it down through the hole from outside the flashlight body. If you try to use pliers to pull on the switch body from the inside, it will probably split in half, the spring will go sprong and dissapear from the face of the earth, and you won't have a button. Just keep prying with the screwdriver or bash it through. This will take a bit of force, but it'll squeeze out eventually. Sacrificing mini-USB cord: snip off the useless end, strip outer insulation. Almost certainly, pos and neg will correspond to red and black wires. You can always plug it in and test to be certain. Snip back the data wires, shielding, and anything else (different levels is nice to make shorting almost impossible), leaving just the positive and negative wires. Strip those a little -- red should be pretty short and black fairly long (red will go to one pole of the switch, black to the LED board. Final Assembly: Break off the four tabs in the button box of the printed part, then feed the USB wire through a hole in the button box of the printed part from outside to inside. Solder the red wire to one pole of the button, then solder another length of wire to the other pole of the button. If the USB cord is loose in its hole, you can add some tape to wedge it in there and it wouldn't hurt to tape over the poles of the switch to prevent anything accidentally running down the USB data lines. Feed the loose positive and negative lines out through another hole, and then slide the button into place. Now you can solder the positive and negative leads to the LED board: red to the positive terminal of the LED board, and black to the negative (big circular pad in the center). The board can then be mounted to the printed bracket with a small screw (FN3). --- Footnotes --- FN1: Flashlight/battery combo -- Just the battery. Ridiculous 29 cent difference in price. FN2: this is for the older 3 LED version. New versions of this flashlight in the store have a single LED. I'm sure it isn't rocket science to get that one out either, but I'm going to wait till the batteries die in my newer flashlights before breaking them down. FN3: I bought a 1000 of these screws and they're very useful: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00GMQDSRI (I'm not trying to flog this product or push the particular seller -- it just took me forever to find some reasonably priced tiny screws and I spent a lot of money on things that turned out to not be what I wanted, so I thought the link might be useful). If you have different size screws, you can always drill the hole out to make use of whatever you have on hand.

comments.text: Just finished making mine using your plans and it worked perfectly! I did end up buying the current version of the eveready 6v LED lantern from home depot for $4.97, and it did indeed only have the single CREE LED chip on it. Compared to your three regular LED's I think the newer chip LED has higher lumens and is brighter. Worked like a champ hooked up to the back of iMac with a 3ft USB cable.

title: Cable Clip 1515 extrusion and Delta enclousure

description.text:
With this we can hide all cables going up from 1515 extrusion and it can be use on horizontal beams too. It can fit a lot of cables, so if you want you can use the arduino board on top of the delta printer. I made it with 100 mm long and I also create an open end so the cable can enter or leave the channel easily.
Then... few months lather I update my design with a new feature!!! I added a groove on each side so you can insert any kind of transparent sheet to create an enclousure, it will help to keep the heat inside and to avoid the cold air to change the print temperature... I turn off my AC everytime I tried to print something. Also the channel to receive the cables have more room and the end piece with the open end is not necessary anymore.
I didn't get the transparent plastic sheet so I don't have any pictures yet on how the delta printer will look like. 
hope it works, please leave me any comments.
thanks
Use sketch up maker 2017 I design a 15x15 open beam profile and create a offset line and then draw the profile.
print it stand up, doesn't use any support and if you need to cut it easy, just use a xacto knife to separate the layers.

author: magic_mushrooms

description.text:
There are already a few great AUAV-X2 cases around but my goal was to make a case that was super light.  I also wanted to provide anyone with the source sketchup files so you can tweak it further.  
This only weights 5 grams.  
Using sketchup, you can make even make it lighter by making the walls thinner, etc.

I used ABS, 0.3mm nozzle, 0.2mm layer height on a Prusa Mendel I3.  I used the Cura slicer with support.  That put support at the ends and the usb entry only.  
I drilled out the mounting holes with a 1/16th drill bit, then threaded a M2 bolt into the hole to make threads.  After that, I mounted the board with M2x4mm Black Nylon Pan Head Screws that I got from ebay.  You can buy 10 for about $1 on ebay or 100 for not much more.  
Remember to cover the barometer with a small piece of open cell foam.

Burj Al Saa or the Clock Tower is one of the most important monuments here in Doha. It is one of the few structures that remained since the 1950s.

This model was constructed by looking at older photographs of the clock tower. Outlines of model were illustrated in Illustrator CC and were exported as a .SVG file. The outlines / clock tower illustration were then imported to 123D Design and was extruded and constructed as a 3D model. Parts of the model is all combined in one piece so that it can be properly 3D printed. Printing with support material is HIGHLY recommended.
